alert.note: Alert for Apache (Arizona) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Advisory issued August 06 at 5:57PM MST by NWS Flagstaff
info.description: ...FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 9 PM MST THIS EVENING... * WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected. * WHERE...A portion of northeast Arizona, including the following counties, Apache and Navajo. * WHEN...Until 900 PM MST. * IMPACTS...Minor flooding in creeks and normally dry washes is imminent or occurring. Dangerous flooding over low-water crossings. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 557 PM MST, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly in the advisory area. Between 1 and 1.75 inches of rain have fallen. - This includes the following creeks, washes and rivers... Dry Creek, Lithodendron Wash, West Twin Wash, Porter Tank Draw, Washboard Wash, East Twin Wash, East Washboard Wash, Fivemile Wash, Little Lithodendron Wash, Little Colorado River, Puerco River, Dead Wash and Carr Lake Draw. Additional rainfall amounts of 0.5 to 1 inch are expected over the area. This additional rain will result in minor flooding. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Holbrook, Sun Valley and Petrified Forest National Park. - This includes the following highways... Interstate 40 between mile markers 287 and 305. Business Interstate 40 between mile markers 286 and 289. State Route 377 between mile markers 25 and 33. State Route 77 between mile markers 375 and 388. Highway 180 between mile markers 308 and 317. - Visit www.weather.gov/safety/flood for more information on flood safety.
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Flooding of washes and creeks will occur, some dirt roads will become muddy and impassable. Paved roads and underpasses could become flooded as well. Remain alert for flooding even in locations not receiving rain. Normally dry washes, slot canyons and creeks can become raging killer currents in a matter of minutes, even from distant rainfall.
